DETROIT TO CLEVELAND
IN 90 MINUTES
Swift - Safe - Delightful — Boats fly only over the
water; and generally only a few feet above the water,
hence a convenient landing space is always available.
" I have traveled over 3,000 miles in an Acromarine Flying Cruiser.
It was a de-
lightful experience, with no soot, no dirt, and without even the danger of ordinary
railroad travel."
(Signed) DR. JAMES W. INCHES, Commissioner of Police.
"The flight to Cleveland is not only the most pleasant and entertaining method of
making the trip,
but i am convinced it is not as dangerous as making the same trip
over the congested highways
(Signed) W. E. METZGER, President, Detroit Athletic Club.
"The flight over the water from Detroit to Cleveland is a most alluring experience
and affords wonderfully beautiful views.
I consider it absolutely safe.
(Signed) COL, SIDNEY D. WALDON, President, Detroit Aviation Society.
Thems chise eror busins races hold see hors unity now to hau
(Signed) HOWARD E. COFFIN, Vice-President, Hudson Motor Car Co.
"The sensation after leaving the water was like a dream, soaring through the won-
derful balmy air ... it is simply beyond description.'
(Signed) IRA C. FARLEY, Vice-President, The Davis & Farley Co.

NINETY
MINUTES
IN HEAVEN
MAR 1 1923
A. & D. R. BLACK
CONSULTING ENGINEERS
25 BRIXTON ROAD
GARDEN CITY, N. Y.
An Interesting Narrative
Describing the FUN, FAS-
CINATION and SAFETY of
"Traveling by Air"
Reproduced by courtesy of The Detroit News

"Played
with the
clouds
and sea
gulls"
"It's
magic,
sublime"
"Rose
into the
blue sky"
Ninety Minutes
in Heaven
as related by
Miss "Peggy" MacLean
HAVE you ever lain flat on your back in a
green
meadow,
day-dreaming,
envying
the little puffs of clouds, and wishing
you
could float with them up in the blue sky? I
played with the clouds and sea gulls yesterday,
figuratively speaking, in their own domain and
many of my air castles came true.
Yesterday I flew to Cleveland for lunch in
the
"Buckeye,
" an 11-passenger flying limou-
sine in the Aeromarine Airway Co.'s service, in
ninety minutes.
It's magic!
If I could only
make you feel my thrills and sensations you
would agree that the world and the inventions
of man have almost attained the sublime.
It
was like being in heaven and looking benevo-
lently down on the little spot of earth known
as the world.
At 9 a. m. we were taken by launch from the
Memorial Park dock out to the flying boat. I
was particularly impressed with the size of the
craft; they are immense, and fitted out with all
the luxuries of a small yacht.
After taxi-ing
around a while to test the motors, we increased
our speed,
traveling up the river like a shot.
Little by little I could feel the boat rise in the
"The islands appeared to be little patches of soft
had the strangest impression of being anchored
in eternity.
Soon we descended almost to the
water and skimmed along a few feet from its
surface.
At Put-in-Bay we passed the sister
aircraft Wolverine on its way from Cleveland
to Detroit.
I went forward into the open to
wave to it; I raised my hand and it came back,
slapping me in the face by the tremendous
pressure of the wind.
The sensation of passing the Wolverine was
one of the important thrills of the trip. My
heart missed three beats!
"Fat,
pompous
man, as
elated as
a small
boy"
A very fat and pompous man in the ship was
as delighted as a small boy.
He sat forever on
the edge of his chair waving a huge handker-
chief at the port hole, even when there was no
one to wave back.
Everyone beamed with
enjoyment and made word pictures or wrote
out their thrills on paper against the roar of
the engines.
"So
Arrived at Cleveland, we gradually floated
elated he
down, nearer and nearer to the water.
almost
Our
landing was exactly like a butterfly kiss, no jar
stuttered" or jolt; we simply caressed the water. When we
reached the dock the pompous man was so
elated with his experience that he almost stut-
tered.
He came within an ace of jumping up
and down and clapping his hands.
I felt as if
he were a kindred spirit and loved him for his
enthusiasm.
The return trip into the heart of the sunset
was even
more exhilarating.
For comfort,
safety, thrills,
and as a remedy against the
cares and disillusionments of the world I can
recommend nothing better than flying.
The world looks wonderful from heaven.
"We were always above the water, therefore,
always had a safe
landing place.
Our landing was exactly like a butterfly's
kiss; no jolt or jar—we simply caressed the water.

OVER BELLE ISLE
Over Belle Isle, which looked like a tiny min-
iature painting, perfect in every detail, a toy
island to delight the heart of anyone possessing
the spirit of youth, we soared. How
take-off and the novelty
of feeling one's self a winged creature?
inspiring. exhilarating!
The worries of the
world fade away with the earth.
There was positively no sensation of a roller
coaster nde
-oh, nothing so earthly as that!
I expected my breath would go
shoes and my heart race madly, but the ascent

Redden, President of the corporation, states

opcration.
on other air routes, not a single

DOWN THE RIVER
We flew down the river.
The little farms of
Canada, in different shades of green, looked for
all the world like tiny drawn
and then
in the corner.
roaos were rooons. wind-
ing in and out, the sidewalks were narrow
little paths.
I never before realized how perfect our little
world is.
Everything seemed to

dump heaps, no dirty downtown streets

cities from above look one extensive park kept
in the neatest order.
Flying is certainly the
happy illusions and
to be able to believe in them
Looking down at the trains and boats, I was

along.

SKIMMING ALONG THE WATER

land, the plane seemed to lose all motion.
